content.name: p
children: Components of any type can specify the endpoints that the container exposes. These endpoints can be made accessible to the users if the {prod-short} cluster is running using a Kubernetes ingress or an OpenShift route and to the other components within the workspace. You can create an endpoint for your application or database, if your application or database server is listening on a port and you want to be able to directly interact with it yourself or you want other components to interact with it.

content.name: h2
children: Procedure

children.name: p
children: Specify endpoints properties as shown in the following example:

children.name: Fence
children:
schemaVersion: 2.1.0
metadata:
  name: mydevfile
projects:
  - name: my-go-project
    clonePath: go/src/github.com/acme/my-go-project
    git:
      remotes:
        origin: "https://github.com/acme/my-go-project.git"
components:
  - name: go
    container:
      image: golang
      memoryLimit: 512Mi
      mountSources: true
      command: ['sleep', 'infinity']
      env:
        - name: gopath
          value: $(PROJECTS_ROOT)/go
        - name: gocache
          value: /tmp/go-cache
      endpoints:
      - name: web
        targetPort: 8080
        exposure: public
  - name: postgres
    container:
      image: postgres
      memoryLimit: 512Mi
      env:
        - name: postgres_user
          value: user
        - name: postgres_password
          value: password
        - name: postgres_db
          value: database
      endpoints:
        - name: postgres
          targetPort: 5432
          exposure: none

content.name: p
children: Here, there are two container, each defining a single endpoint. Endpoint
is an accessible port that can be made accessible inside the workspace
or publicly from the UI. Each endpoint has a name and port, which is the
port on which certain server running inside the container is listening.
The following are a few attributes that you can set on the endpoint:

children.name: p
code
children: exposure
: When its value is

children.name: code
children: public
, the endpoint is accessible outside the workspace. Users can
access such an endpoint from the {prod-short} user interface and is always exposed on port
or
depending on whether TLS is enabled in {prod-short}.

code
children: protocol
: For public endpoints, the protocol is a hint to the UI
on how to construct the URL for the endpoint access. Typical values
are

children.name: code
children: http

children.name: code
children: https

children.name: code
children: ws

children.name: code
children: wss

children.name: p
code
children: secure
: A boolean defaulting to

children.name: code
children: false
that specifies whether the
endpoint is put behind a JWT proxy requiring a JWT workspace token
to grant access. The JWT proxy is deployed in the same Pod as the
server and assumes the server listens solely on the local loopback
interface, such as

children.name: p
children: Listening on any other interface than the local loopback poses a
security risk because such server is accessible without the JWT
authentication within the cluster network on the corresponding IP
addresses.

children.name: p
code
children: path
: The URL of the endpoint.

content.name: p
children: When starting a new server within a component, {prod-short} autodetects this, and the UI offers to automatically expose this port as an

children.name: code
children: exposure

port. This exposure is useful for debugging a web application. It is impossible to do this for servers that autostart with the container, for example, a database server. For such components, specify the endpoints explicitly.

content.name: Fence

attributes.title: Specifying endpoints for kubernetes or openshift types

children:
schemaVersion: 2.1.0
metadata:
  name: mydevfile
components:
  - openshift:
      name: webapp
      uri: webapp.yaml
      endpoints:
      - name: 'web'
        targetPort: 8080
        exposure: public
  - openshift:
      name: mongo
      uri: mongo-db.yaml
      endpoints:
      - name: 'mongo-db'
        targetPort: 27017
        exposure: public
